questions.text: A 26-year-old male is rushed to the emergency department of a tertiary care hospital in India after being bitten by a snake while working in the fields. He has no significant medical history. On examination, he is anxious, with a bite mark visible on his lower right leg. Within hours, he develops hematuria and laboratory tests indicate a rapid deterioration in renal function. The medical team considers the type of enzyme present in the snake venom that might be responsible for these clinical findings. Which enzyme in snake venom is known to cause hematuria and renal function deterioration?

Ans. D)

questions.text: A pediatrician evaluating a 6-month-old girl brought in by her mother. The baby has a history of repeated infections, fever, vomiting, and one seizure episode. There's a significant family history: an elder brother passed away at 3 years old from an undiagnosed condition. The baby appears lethargic and hypotonic, with bilateral nystagmus and a cherry red spot visible in both eyes. A blood examination reveals a decreased level of Hexosaminidase A enzyme, prompting the pediatrician to consider a genetic metabolic disorder. What is the most probable diagnosis for this baby?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Tay-Sachs disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A: Gaucher’s disease type 1 : Due to deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase, C/F: Enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, no mental retardation, no cherry red spot
  • • Option A: Gaucher’s disease type 1
  • • Option B: Niemann Pick disease : Due to deficiency of Sphingomyelinase. C/F: Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness, hepatosplenomegaly with Cherry red spot in macula. Death by 2 years of age.
  • • Option B: Niemann Pick disease
  • • Option D: Sandhoff’s disease : Due to deficiency of Hexosaminidase A and B, c/f: Neurological deficit and MR with cherry red spot.
  • • Option D: Sandhoff’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder characterized by the absence or insufficient activity of an enzyme called Hexosaminidase A, leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside within lysosomes, causing progressive neurological damage.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper 30/e: p 68,251.

Laboratory investigations revealed the following critical findings: Blood sugar: 25 mg/dL, indicating profound hypoglycemia. Elevated levels of medium-chain acylcarnitines. questions.text: A 55-year-old obese woman visits her primary care physician complaining of recurrent episodes of mild epigastric pain and vomiting, particularly after consuming fatty meals. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the epigastric region. Given the patient's symptoms and risk factors, the physician suspects a biliary tract disorder and refers her for an abdominal ultrasound, which confirms the presence of gallstones in the gallbladder. One of the stones appears to be lodged in the upper part of the bile duct, potentially impacting bile flow and digestion. A gallstone obstructing the upper part of the bile duct would most likely lead to an increase in which of the following?

options.label: B
options.text: Excretion of bile salts & Conjugation of bile acids

options.label: C
options.text: The excretion of fats in the feces

questions.correct_answer: C. The excretion of fats in the feces
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Formation of chylomicrons : Chylomicrons are formed in the intestinal cells to transport absorbed fats , including triglycerides, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins , from the intestines to other parts of the body . Bile duct obstruction does not directly affect chylomicron formation but impacts fat absorption, which indirectly could affect chylomicron content.
  • • Option A: Formation of chylomicrons
  • • Chylomicrons
  • • intestinal cells
  • • absorbed fats
  • • triglycerides, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins
  • • intestines

  • • body

  • • not

  • • fat absorption,
  • • indirectly
  • • chylomicron
  • • Option B: Excretion of bile salts & Conjugation of bile acids : Bile salts and bile acids are involved in the emulsification of fats and are recycled via the enterohepatic circulation. While obstruction can lead to decreased bile flow into the intestine, it primarily affects fat absorption rather than the excretion or conjugation of bile components.
  • • Option B: Excretion of bile salts & Conjugation of bile acids

  • • recycled
  • • enterohepatic circulation.
  • • obstruction

  • • intestine,

  • • fat absorption
  • • excretion or conjugation
  • • bile components.
  • • Option D: Recycling of bile salts : The recycling of bile salts is part of the enterohepatic circulation, where bile salts are reabsorbed from the intestines and returned to the liver. A blockage in the bile duct might disrupt this recycling process , but the more immediate effect is on fat absorption and fecal fat excretion.
  • • Option D: Recycling of bile salts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gallstones are made up of cholesterol, calcium bilirubinate and bile salts. All the above given details such as female, middle-aged, and overweight shows the patient has gallbladder disease. FUNCTION : The gallbladder stores bile salts produced by the liver and when it is contracted by the entry of food → bile salts travel through the bile duct to the duodenum → causes emulsification of fats , thereby helping in digestion of fat. When the solutes in the gallbladder precipitate , they form gallstones. Patients may have pain from the gallstones, usually after a fatty meal . The pain sites are epigastric or right upper quadrant, which radiates to the right shoulder . Also, cholecystitis and pancreatitis ( stones → bile duct - > obstruct biliary flow → jaundice or irritate the pancreas ). Obstruction of bile duct → bile salts cannot enter the digestive tract → recycling and excretion of bile salts , digestion of fats and formation of chylomicrons are decreased → fats in the feces are increased (Steatorrhea).
  • ➤ Gallstones are made up of cholesterol, calcium bilirubinate and bile salts.

questions.text: Assertion (A): Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a glycogen storage disease characterized by mental retardation, organomegaly, etc. Reasoning (R): This is due to deficiency of enzyme hexosaminidase A. Select the correct option:

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A and R both are wrong

options.label: C
options.text: A is wrong but R is a right statement

options.label: D
options.text: A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

questions.correct_answer: B. A and R both are wrong
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. A and R both are wrong

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Assertion (A) is wrong because Metachromatic Leukodystrophy (MLD) is not a glycogen storage disease . It is a lysosomal storage disorder that belongs to the group of sphingolipidoses , caused by a deficiency in the enzyme arylsulfatase A . This leads to the accumulation of sulfatides , particularly sulfogalactocerebroside , resulting in demyelination of white matter , particularly in the central and peripheral nervous systems.

  • • Progressive neurological deterioration
  • • neurological deterioration
  • • Behavioral changes , motor regression
  • • Behavioral changes

  • • Demyelination , often leading to spasticity and paralysis

  • • Tay-Sachs
  • • lysosomal storage disorder
  • • accumulation of GM2 gangliosides

questions.text: What is the relationship between this finding and the function of LCAT? Assertion (A): Excess cholesterol in the cell is esterified into cholesterol ester and is stored up there. Reasoning (R): LCAT converts free cholesterol to the cholesterol ester and plays a major role in reverse cholesterol transport.

options.label: A
options.text: A and R both are wrong

options.label: B
options.text: A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

options.label: C
options.text: A is wrong but R is a right statement

options.label: D
options.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A

questions.correct_answer: D. A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Assertion (A) is correct — excess intracellular cholesterol is esterified and stored in the cholesterol pool within cells. This esterification allows for non-toxic storage of cholesterol in lipid droplets. However, the enzyme responsible for this process is ACAT (Acyl-CoA:cholesterol acyltransferase) , which is intracellular , not LCAT. Reason (R) is also correct — LCAT (Lecithin:cholesterol acyltransferase) is a plasma enzyme bound to HDL , and it converts free cholesterol (acquired from peripheral tissues) into cholesterol esters as part of reverse cholesterol transport , allowing HDL to carry cholesterol back to the liver.
  • • Assertion (A) is correct — excess intracellular cholesterol is esterified and stored in the cholesterol pool within cells. This esterification allows for non-toxic storage of cholesterol in lipid droplets.

  • • intracellular
  • • Reason (R) is also correct — LCAT (Lecithin:cholesterol acyltransferase) is a plasma enzyme bound to HDL , and it converts free cholesterol (acquired from peripheral tissues) into cholesterol esters as part of reverse cholesterol transport , allowing HDL to carry cholesterol back to the liver.
  • • Reason (R)
  • • correct
  • • LCAT (Lecithin:cholesterol acyltransferase)
  • • plasma enzyme
  • • HDL
  • • free cholesterol
  • • cholesterol esters
  • • reverse cholesterol transport
  • • Why R is not the correct explanation of A:
  • • Why R is not the correct explanation of A:
  • • LCAT esterifies plasma cholesterol during transport on HDL , not cholesterol in the intracellular cholesterol pool , which is the focus of A. The esterification of cholesterol for storage inside cells is performed by ACAT , not LCAT.

questions.text: Match the following enzymes with the pathway they are involved in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • HMG CoA Reductase is a key enzyme in the biosynthesis of cholesterol , catalyzing the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate , a rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis. Hence, 1-b is correct . 7-alpha-hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the formation of bile acids from cholesterol . It catalyzes the introduction of a hydroxyl group at the 7th position of the steroid nucleus of cholesterol, which is the first step in the classical pathway of bile acid synthesis . Thus, 2-a is correct. Thiophorase , also known as succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid coenzyme A transferase (SCOT), is involved in ketolysis, particularly in the utilization of ketone bodies by the tissues outside the liver, converting acetoacetate into acetoacetyl-CoA. Therefore, 3-d is accurate. Carnitine acyl transferase I is a crucial enzyme in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids . It facilitates the transport of fatty acids into the mitochondria for oxidation by converting them into their acyl-carnitine derivatives , which can cross the mitochondrial membrane . Hence, 4-c is correct.

questions.text: Assertion (A): Bile acid protects the body from cholesterol over production. Reasoning (R): In liver, choles terol is continuously converted to bile acid.

options.label: A
options.text: A and R both are right, but R is not the correct explanation of A

options.label: B
options.text: A is wrong but R is a right statement

options.label: C
options.text: A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A

options.label: D
options.text: A and R both are wrong

questions.correct_answer: C. A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Assertion (A) is correct. Bile acids , which are derived from cholesterol, play a significant role in maintaining cholesterol homeostasis within the body. By converting cholesterol into bile acids , the body can regulate the levels of cholesterol, preventing its overproduction and accumulation , which can lead to conditions such as hypercholesterolemia and atherosclerosis.
  • • Assertion (A)
  • • correct. Bile acids
  • • derived
  • • cholesterol,
  • • role
  • • cholesterol homeostasis
  • • body.
  • • cholesterol into bile acids
  • • levels of cholesterol, preventing
  • • overproduction and accumulation
  • • hypercholesterolemia and atherosclerosis.
  • • Reasoning (R) is also correct and provides a correct explanation for Assertion (A) . The liver plays a crucial role in lipid metabolism , including the conversion of cholesterol into bile acids . This conversion is an important regulatory mechanism for controlling cholesterol levels in the body. Bile acids are then excreted into the intestine with bile , where they aid in the digestion and absorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. Some bile acids are reabsorbed from the intestine and returned to the liver, while others are lost in the feces . This loss of bile acids from the body necessitates the conversion of more cholesterol into bile acids, thus helping to regulate cholesterol levels and prevent overproduction.

questions.text: A neurologist is assessing a teenage girl who has been experiencing fatigue severe enough to prevent her participation in physical education classes. She presents with muscle weakness in her limbs. Lab tests indicate high serum levels of triacylglycerols esterified with long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) and hypoglycemia. A muscle biopsy shows an abundance of lipid vacuoles. What condition do these clinical findings suggest?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Affects the de novo synthesis of fatty acids occurs in the cytoplasm with the help of a dimeric multi-enzyme complex termed Fatty acid synthase .

  • • de novo synthesis

  • • dimeric multi-enzyme complex
  • • Fatty acid synthase
  • • Option C: Deficiency of hexosaminidase A leads to accumulation of Ganglioside (GM2). C/F - Mental retardation, Cherry red spot in the macula with Progressive deterioration and death by 3–4 years.
